Award.AwardTitle: Air-Sea Fluxes of Momentum, Heat, and Carbon Dioxide at High Wind Speeds in the Southern Ocean
Award.AbstractNarration:
Accurate parameterizations of the air-sea fluxes of CO2 into the Southern Ocean, in particular at high wind velocity, are needed to better assess how projections of global climate warming in a windier world could affect the ocean carbon uptake, and alter the ocean heat budget at high latitudes.

Air-sea fluxes of momentum, sensible and latent heat (water vapor) and carbon dioxide (CO2) are to be measured continuously underway on cruises using micrometeorological eddy covariance techniques adapted to ship-board use. The measured gas transfer velocity (K) is then to be related to other parameters known to affect air-sea-fluxes.

A stated goal of this work is the collection of a set of direct air-sea flux measurements at high wind speeds, conditions where parameterization of the relationship of gas exchange to wind-speed remains contentious. The studies will be carried out at sites in the Southern Ocean using the USAP RV Nathaniel B Palmer as measurment platform. Co-located pCO2 data, to be used in the overall analysis and enabling internal consistency checks, are being collected from existing underway systems aboard the USAP research vessel under other NSF awards.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Southern Ocean is a net carbon sink, accounting for roughly half of anthropogenic carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions absorbed by the global ocean. The main goal of this project was to determine how air-sea CO2 gas exchange depends on wind speed during high winds characteristic of the Southern Ocean. To achieve this goal, we made direct measurements of air-sea fluxes (momentum, heat, moisture, CO2) from the U.S. polar ship RVIB Nathaniel B. Palmer (NBP) during 9 cruises over 18 months in 2013-2014. While the original intent was to collect data in the open ocean, by serendipity a considerable fraction of the data was obtained in the Antarctic marginal ice zone, which enabled us to address additional scientific questions.  

 

We designed the first air-sea CO2 flux system that can operate unattended in the harsh conditions of the Southern Ocean and Antarctic marginal ice zone. This technological achievement paves the way for collection of data that can be used to drive models and test and improve air-sea flux algorithms (e.g., Southern Ocean Observing System - SOOS). This project produced by far the largest Southern Ocean open-water CO2 flux data set to date, and the first CO2 flux data in the Antarctic marginal ice zone. The results of this study affect large-scale estimates of carbon balance in the Southern Ocean and the Antarctic marginal ice zone, such as reported in the IPCC reports, and therefore may ultimately impact policy decisions.

 

Scientifically, the open-ocean data showed a quadratic relationship between wind speed and the gas transfer velocity that is nearly identical to the parameterization of Wanninkhof (2014). Our data contrast with the previous results (e.g., GasEx-98) that suggested a cubic relationship. We also found non-zero gas transfer in the limit of zero wind speed (i.e., an offset term in the quadratic relationship). This offset is plausible due to other sources of waterside turbulence besides wind. In the sea ice zone, we found the gas transfer velocity to decrease in proportion with the fraction of sea ice cover. This scaling is typically used to calculate regional carbon budgets, but had not been verified by field measurements. Our results in the marginal ice zone contrast with a recent model of high-latitude air-sea gas exchange that predicts gas exchange is strongly enhanced in the presence of sea ice. In the sea ice zone, our results will provide an important benchmark for the development of models and high-latitude carbon budget studies.

 

This project supported the PhD research of Brian Butterworth at the State University of New York at Albany from 2012-2016. Brian successfully defended his PhD dissertation in July 2016 and accepted a postdoctoral researcher position at the University of Calgary, doing research in the Arctic that builds on his graduate work. He has expressed a desire to return to academia/research in the US following his post-doc. Brian first-authored two papers describing the results of this project, one in the Journal of Atmospheric and Oceanic Technology and the other in Geophysical Research Letters (GRL). 

 

This project supported a technician, Chris Sager, who helped design and test strategies for mitigating the impacts of ice buildup on sensors, using the University at Albany Whiteface Mountain Observatory as a testbed facility. An undergraduate student, Zach Szumloz, worked on implementing techniques in Matlab to extract ice fraction from the digital camera images collected continuously from NBP. 

 

This project supported fieldwork, including 3 trips to Punta Arenas, Chile, by Miller and Butterworth, participation in a 40-day cruise by Butterworth and a 7-day transit by Butterworth and Miller. The project results were presented at the 2013 SOLAS summer school (China), 2014 Ocean Sciences meeting (Hawaii), 2015 Gas Transfer at Water Surfaces meeting (Seattle), 2015 AMS Air-Sea Interaction meeting (Phoenix), 2015 Southern Ocean Observing System (SOOS) Air-Sea Flux meeting (Frascati, Italy), and will be presented at the upcoming “Air-Sea Gas Flux: Progress and Future Prospects” meeting (Brest, France). Data from two of the nine cruises have been made available on the PIs website (http://asrc.albany.edu/southern_ocean), submitted as supporting information with the GRL paper, and archived with the Marine Geosciences Data System (http://www.marine-geo.org).
